Hi,
  Quick answer : "yes". As parasitism-based and neoteny-based evolution=
 can be roughly and subjectively put into an algo. As far as some selection=
 scheme is integrated, it will even "work", ie. provide solutions better th=
an the initial population. But then, maybe I'm close-minded, but I see thre=
e paths :

    - Biologic model =3D> So we try to be accurate and we fit th=
e model to *real* data and test it over *real* data. Every details count, e=
ven the weird proteins mechanic in the cells nucleus. So far, not the main =
stream evolutionary computation work.

    - Optimization algorithm =3D> So=
 we don't give a damn about biology and we leave it to biologist. We design=
 algorithms  to solve problems, therefore the design choice are made accord=
ing to that objective. Optimizing seems the main focus on the evolutionary =
computation community.

    - Open experimentation & tweaking =3D> Put here=
 whatever you like, including algorithm interpretation of whatever biologic=
 phenomenon we hear about. No goal out of... Watching what happens. it's we=
 discover unknown stuffs, usually.

So indeed, whatever you like is ok, as =
far you give yourself an objective. If you want to optimize, horizontal evo=
lution, well, gimme rational explanations better than "nature does it". If =
you want to do models, yeah, can be very very cool to compare to models wit=
hout horizontal evolution. If it's for fun, yeah, can make a nice personal =
project ^^

Alex

  =
    This is an interesting article.

http://www.newscien tist.com/ article/=
mg205274 41.500-horizonta l-and-vertical- the-evolution- of-evolution. html=
?full=3D true&print=3D true



It talks essentially about the process that =
gave rise to the evolutionary algorithm and protein synthesis machinery.


=

I wonder if you could use something like it to tweak or build an evolution=
ary algorithm?



What do you guys think?
